list.title: Between Two Selves
list.dek: Between Two Selves is Michael Bouldry-Morrison’s debut LP, and represents the next step in a steady refinement of the Octo Octa formula he has perfected on releases for 100% Silk. Warehouse-ready techno and dreamlike deep house are among the genres he employs to explore themes of personal fulfillment and identity.

list.title: Secondhand Rapture
list.dek: The Brooklyn-based electro-pop duo follows their 2012 EP Candy Bar Creep Show with a full-length of brooding, rhythmically strong pop songs that fall halfway between the poutiness of Lana Del Rey and the hyperactive fizz of HAIM.

list.dek: Sunday School II improves on its first installment in almost every aspect: The songs are stronger, the Chicago rapper's performance more assured, and the "soul trap" production-- with assistance from producer Michael Kolar-- is deeper and denser.

list.title: Hecla & Griper EP
list.dek: At the time of Jason Molina's death this past March, he and his lifelong label Secretly Canadian were planning to reissue records from the darker corners of his catalog. The first to see the light is the Hecla & Griper EP, a disarmingly raw and unbounded, unpolished set of songs.

list.title: Impersonator
list.dek: Impersonator is Devon Welsh and Matthew Otto's second album as Majical Cloudz. Like their live shows, it is searingly, emotionally direct, extraordinarily sung, and hypnotically focused, made special by Welsh's sense of emotional urgency.

list.title: Tactile Galactics
list.dek: Eddie Ruscha Jr.'s latest album is the first full-length release for Beats in Space, a new label established by WNYU DJ Tim Sweeney. It's a graceful and intricate record that flashes past with a similar stylistic blur to Ruscha Jr.'s Tropical Psychedelics compilation, tracing trancey vintage synth patterns that circle around one another.

list.title: Dreams in the Rat House
list.dek: Dreams in the Rat House combines the off-the-cuff hijinks and threadbare fidelity of Shannon and the Clams' debut, I Wanna Go Home with the songwriting focus of their great second effort, Sleep Talk, while exhibiting the fine art of making it all look easy.

list.title: Survival
list.dek: Hunter Hunt-Hendrix of Liturgy's latest side-project sees him playing with older friends, including Krallice guitarist Colin Marston. Their debut is a more straightforward, grounded work than that of Liturgy, though twists in a way familiar to fans of Hunt-Hendrix's music.

list.title: Behind the Green Door EP
list.dek: Less than a year since Laurel Halo released her debut full-length for Hyperdub, she returns with a four-track EP for the label. If Quarantine resembled an amalgam of flesh and machine, here Halo goes one step closer to erasing humanity from the frame by including none of her trademark vocal swoops.

list.title: Trouble Will Find Me
list.dek: The National's sixth album is their leanest and most aerodynamic, easily accessible and self-assured by virtue of focusing on the visceral power of Matt Berninger's vocals and Bryan Devendorf's taut, inventive drumming. It's also their funniest, and most self-referential.

list.title: Sqürl EP
list.dek: Director Jim Jarmusch has been increasingly hung up on music since shooting his last feature, The Limits of Control. After releasing two albums with lutist Jozef Van Wissem, his new band SQÜRL comprises Carter Logan and Vampire Weekend engineer Shane Stoneback, and draws on feedback, drone, and song-based disciplines.

list.title: Marriage of Metals / Vilke
list.dek: Over the last two decades, the Portland, OR, musician has built dozens of massive, teeming spans of sound, deliberately sculpting a cacophony of static and rhythm into objects of inescapable gravity. Even though his discography is vast, these two albums are clear standouts.

list.title: It's Up to Emma
list.dek: It's Up to Emma, Scout Niblett's seventh album, is her best since her debut, full of raw power as it obsessively follows the aftermath of a toxic relationship through the various Kübler-Ross stages. It's also her first without Steve Albini producing, and is markedly fancier for it.

list.title: Sing to the Moon
list.dek: This classically trained Brit's debut album has seen her compared to the likes of Nina Simone and David Axelrod. Although her lyrics sometimes communicate an impersonal strain of melancholy, the music is anything but, dazzling with powerful, vibrant arrangements.

list.title: Random Access Memories
list.dek: Daft Punk's new album Random Access Memories finds them leaving behind the highly influential, riff-heavy EDM they originated to luxuriate in the sounds, styles, and production techniques of the 1970s and early 80s.

list.title: Tectonic Plates Vol. 4
list.dek: The Bristol-based Tectonic Plates compilations have long functioned as a sort of state-of-the-nation for the label. Last year’s Vol. 3 seemed firmly entrenched in dubstep, and while Vol. 4 has by no means abandoned the 140 bpm template, it feels far less wedded to the past.

list.title: The Last Spire
list.dek: The Last Spire is the British metal quartet's final LP, and it ends exactly as the band started out, heads down in heavy doom. There's a back-to-basics approach here, which reconnects with Cathedral's beginnings without simply repeating them. But it's uncharacteristically restrained, too.

list.title: No One Dances Quite Like My Brothers
list.seoTitle: No One Dances Quite Like My Brothers
list.socialTitle: No One Dances Quite Like My Brothers
list.promoTitle: No One Dances Quite Like My Brothers
list.dek: Comprising Iceage's Elias Bender Rønnenfelt, Loke Rahbek of Sexdrome, and Kristian Emdal of Lower, along with Lukas Højland, the Copenhagen punks' debut album is as open and vulnerable as their other bands are clenched and impervious, bending the same apocalyptic impulse in a serene, even sensuous direction.

list.title: Black Pudding
list.dek: Mark Lanegan is back to working with a musical co-pilot here, though British multi-instrumentalist Duke Garwood's accompaniments are rather subsumed by Lanegan's outsized personality. Black Pudding offers scarifying dirges and tough-guy sensitivity in reliable abundance.

list.title: The Great Gatsby OST
list.dek: The soundtrack to Baz Luhrmann's film adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel was executive produced by Jay-Z, who saw the story as a familiar tale of aspiration. But the result, featuring new and previously released tracks from the xx, Beyoncé, Florence Welch, and more, is garish and joyless.

list.title: Raw Solutions
list.dek: The debut album by Moscow-born, Chicago-raised, Brooklyn-based producer Slava can offer the armchair musicologist hours of entertainment dissecting his attempt to reunite house's splintered factions. Analysis aside, it's also a very solid collection of viscerally compelling dance music.

list.title: Dungeonesse
list.dek: The debut album from Wye Oak's Jenn Wasner and White Life's Jon Ehrens recreates the omnipresent 90s pop that permeated their childhoods with aplomb. Dungeonesse is sparkling, intimate, and not nearly as self-conscious as you might expect, though it could lose the awkward raps.

list.title: Abandon
list.dek: This Sacred Bones LP is Margaret Chardiet's most high-profile Pharmakon release to date, following a series of hard-to-find CD-Rs and cassettes. It takes cues from Throbbing Gristle, Swans, and Whitehouse among others, and proves a bodily, antagonistic listen.

list.title: Re-Mit
list.dek: Maintaining the same line-up as on the Fall's preceding three albums, the loosely structured Re-Mit falls somewhere between their best album of the past decade, Your Future Our Clutter, and their worst, Ersatz G.B. Mark E. Smith even comes off halfway happy, but it's all relative.

list.title: False Prism
list.dek: After releasing a handful of demos and splits with other Philly bands Ominous Black and Grass, doom metal duo Sadgiqacea inked a deal with semi-local indie powerhouse Candlelight. The result, False Prism, is an impressive debut album, and a beginning to this next chapter in the tale of a little band that could.

list.title: Hard Coming Down
list.dek: Hard Coming Down is Gun Outfit's third LP for Dean Spunt of No Age's label Post Present Medium, and their best yet. It underscores their combination of lo-fi K Records abandon and SST crunch for a dusky, slowcore approach that's executed with grace.

list.title: Black Beauty
list.dek: Love's lost labor, Black Beauty, was recorded in 1973 but shelved for nearly four decades. This release, via High Moon Records, shows off the crisp production of Paul Rothchild and Arthur Lee's ability to build from a potent blues rock rock foundation.

list.title: LSXX
list.dek: The expanded 20th anniversary edition of the Breeders' breakthrough affirms its status as an alt-rock classic. The set includes a 1994 live show and a disc of rarities and demos that put the finished product in context. Meanwhile, the EPs from the period show off the wide stylistic range of everything the Breeders could do well.

list.title: Bruits et Temps Analogues
list.dek: 1976's Bruits et Temps Analogues is the French musician and former member of prog-leaning group Red Noise's sole solo album, where he cooks up a form of cosmic jazz made with the aid of various Moog and ARP synths, plus a backing band that includes drummer Mino Cinelu.

list.title: Mind Control
list.dek: Europe's putting in heavy work on the retro metal front at the moment, with Uncle Acid and the Deadbeats following Kadavar, the Devil's Blood, Graveyard, and more. They take the core guitar sound of Pentagram ca. 1970 and meld it to the foreboding gloom of their 1980s work.

list.title: The Way Things Fall
list.dek: Most of ADULT.’s electroclash-affiliated contemporaries have fallen off the map, and the post-millennial tension that made them seem so timely in the early 2000s has evolved into something different. But that sense of deep alienation still pervades the duo’s fifth album.

list.title: Green: 25th Anniversary Deluxe Edition
list.dek: Green is defined by the tweaks R.E.M. made to their creative process, by the restlessness that destroys many bands but somehow revitalized these four musicians. The 1988 album marked many firsts for the band-- their first major label effort, their first LP to go double platinum, the first to achieve popularity in the UK.

list.title: Acid: Mysterons Invade the Jackin' Zone
list.seoTitle: Acid: Mysterons Invade the Jackin' Zone
list.socialTitle: Acid: Mysterons Invade the Jackin' Zone
list.promoTitle: Acid: Mysterons Invade the Jackin' Zone
list.dek: By manipulating the Roland TB-303 Bass Line synthesizer, Chicago trio Phuture ignited a craze that came to be called "acid house" in 1985. Though their 12-minute opus "Acid Tracks" isn't on Soul Jazz's two disc survey Acid: Mysterons Invade the Jackin’ Zone, the compilation's 22 songs give a thorough overview of the genre's local legacy.

list.dek: Kingdom of Conspiracy isn't a state-of-the-art death metal record, but it is a state-of-the-art Immolation LP, and its continuation of the band's expertly calibrated blend of the byzantine and the straightforwardly brutal proves once more that they're one of the most rewarding veteran acts in the genre.

list.title: Replicant Moods
list.dek: It's hard to picture the Los Angeles four-piece's debut album as the work of a group, as it has more in common with the quiet elation of lone producers like John Talabot. Pharaohs are most interested in inhabiting a comedown-leaning zone, and their contemporary take on popular dance tropes will be familiar to fans of the DFA label.

list.dek: Grain is the first release by the latest Zs lineup-- saxophonist Sam Hillmer, guitarist Patrick Higgins, and ex-Liturgy drummer Greg Fox. list.title: Fain
list.dek: With its amped-up Brit-folk melodies, pastoral bent, and occasional flute, Wolf People's second LP is a rock collection that harkens to a time when fife-toting beardos decamped to hillsides to write 18 minute songs about wizards. It's prog, but is it progressive?

list.dek: The Detroit producer's third proper album is a love letter to a few things Omar pretends not to care about: his fans, his hometown, and house music. Here, he berates us with kindness, offering wistful, major-key tracks out of step with his reputation for hissy lo-fi concoctions.

list.title: Teethed Glory and Injury
list.dek: The third LP from Altar of Plagues is a dense, demanding record where black metal slams against industrial throb, and noise sheets work alongside diaphanous electronics. It suggests the heyday of Touch and Go, Nine Inch Nails in their prime, or Swans at their vitrolic apex.

list.title: Praxis Makes Perfect
list.dek: Super Furry Animals' Gruff Rhys and Bryan Hollon (aka Boom Bip) continue their pursuit of the album-biopic by dedicating Neon Neon's second full-length to the life of Giangiacomo Feltrinelli, a wealthy Italian scion turned left-wing political activist and publisher, to the tune of deceptively plasticized synth pop.

list.title: Songs Cycled
list.dek: Van Dyke Parks' Songs Cycled collects six 7" singles he's released over the past few years. A lot of what's here has appeared before, elsewhere and in different forms, and then there's the traditional music that belongs to nobody. Like all his albums, it's cheerful and maddeningly detailed.

list.title: Monomania
list.dek: On Deerhunter’s swaggering fifth album, Monomania, they almost completely jettison the dreamy ambience that usually characterizes their work in favor of straight-up raw, bleeding garage rock, populating the songs with junkyards, leather jackets, and motorcycles.

list.title: Private Airplane
list.dek: Connections' debut album bears an obvious debt to fellow Ohians Guided By Voices' Bee Thousand, but as Columbus lifers (their drummer was in Times New Viking) they get away with it, offering as good a pass at 90s-style guitar rock as you're likely to get outside of the decade.

list.title: Eglo Records Vol. 1
list.dek: Alex Rogers and Sam Shepherd's Eglo Records emerged in 2009 and has since functioned as a bridge between the increasingly fragmented identity of London's dancefloors and global currents in contemporary soul. Eglo Records Volume I is their largest project to date and functions as a consolidation of the successes of those early years.

list.title: Ghosts Go Blind
list.dek: David Wingo's third album as Ola Podrida puts his role as a composer for film in the shade, proving an abruptly extroverted and thoroughly satisfying record that thrives on the vigorous execution of some familiar, genre-specific sounds: think the Clientele, Interpol, and even Coldplay.

list.title: Everybody Loves Sausages
list.dek: The covers album Everybody Loves Sausages is a tour through the Melvin's most beloved songs, hitting most of the expected bases (Venom, Throbbing Gristle) with a few surprises (Queen, Roxy Music). Mudoney's Mark Arm, Jello Biafra, Neurosis' Scott Kelly, J.G. Thirwell, Clem Burke of Blondie, and others, offer guest vocals.

list.title: MCII
list.dek: On Mikal Cronin's first album for Merge, the Ty Segall collaborator balances the "power" and "pop" elements of his sound with aplomb, while sounding utterly out of sync internally. It's pop poetry for the aloof, and Cronin's most fully realized, beautifully arranged, well-crafted work to date.

list.title: Fabric 69
list.dek: Darkness reigned supreme for influential techno label/collective Sandwell District, which shuttered its operations in 2012. This sprawling, lavish 75-minute Fabric 69 mix, the first release in two years to bear the SD name, isn't meant to signal a new beginning for the collective as much as it's a menacing, immersive summation.

list.title: English Little League
list.dek: English Little League is Guided by Voices' fourth LP since their comeback, meaning they've now made as many post-hiatus LPs as they managed during their "classic era." Amidst the booming arena-rockers, swift power-pop, proggy bluster, and wads of bubblegum, it marks the first appearance of recordings from Bob Pollard's new home-studio.

list.title: Thr!!!er
list.dek: Thirteen years and five LPs into !!!'s output, the mostly well-turned but low-impact Thr!!!er has all the hallmarks of the Brooklyn punk-funk band-- wiry, kinked guitars, ropy bass lines, popping handclaps, chanting choruses, and falsetto outbursts-- minus a crucial one: abandon.

list.title: Acrobatic Tenement / Relationship of Command
list.dek: At the Drive-In stuck around long enough to have an unequivocal impact and burned out before they could wear out their welcome. Now, without much fanfare, the charismatic El Paso post-hardcore band are reissuing their 1996 debut Acrobatic Tenement and their 2000 swan song Relationship of Command.

list.dek: The Stooges' fifth album Ready to Die avoids the pitfalls of 2007's disastrous reunion album The Weirdness, but 40 years removed from the kamikaze death-trip fantasies of Raw Power, it's the sound of Iggy admitting, “I’m too old for this shit.”

list.title: Withdrawal
list.dek: Mixing hardcore, black metal, and thrash, the Brooklyn-via-Philadelphia quartet Woe's excellent, ambitious Withdrawal is an unforgiving record with an unbroken focus. The intricacy of the band's music-- and there’s plenty of it-- doesn’t interfere with its immediacy.

list.title: Sister Faith
list.dek: The Louisville punk trio Coliseum's J Robbins-produced fourth album covers the inevitability of death, the absurdity of faith, and what it means to be alive when everything ends. But it's also fun: In terms of pure chugging rock'n'roll, it sits comfortably next to Torche and Baroness.

list.title: ½ Gentlemen / Not Beasts
list.dek: Fire Records' 4xLP reissue of Half Japanese's ½ Gentlemen / Not Beasts demonstrates how the Fair brothers' caveman racket anticipated the work of acts such as Daniel Johnston and Beat Happening; it's a brilliant mix of loud punk blasts, shapeless rants, heartfelt confessions, and minimal experiments.

list.title: Oblivion OST

list.dek: The Athens-based cosmic country band Futurebirds' second full-length nails the melancholy of trying to chase and pin down something that's special and fleeting. It does so with a loose-limbed tangle of reverbed guitars, hollered harmonies, and driving Southern rock rhythms.

list.title: To Be Close to You
list.dek: The hushed and lovely Maryland indie pop outfit's first official release was recorded straight to tape, and the resulting sound world is a reward in itself for hardcore cassette fans. These are warm, reassuring-- if mordant-- songs that recall Elliott Smith, or K Records-era Modest Mouse.

These are warm, reassuring-- if mordant-- songs that recall Elliott Smith, or K Records-era Modest Mouse.

list.dek: Föllakzoid hail from Santiago, Chile. But with their rigid rhythms, their chemtrail synths, their afterburner guitars, their sound is pure Düsseldorf, circa 1971. And this krautrock-worshiping quartet's fascination with all things kosmische isn't merely musical.

list.title: Bored Nothing
list.dek: Fergus Miller, aka Bored Nothing, wrote these songs while bumming semi-homeless around Australia, and the characters in his songs are perpetually stoned, bored, or existentially lost. It's familiar territory, but Miller has a way with words and a refreshing clear-eyed honesty.

list.title: Chunky Monkey
list.dek: On New York-based sound designer Aaron David Ross' Chunky Monkey, there's palpable sense of excitement to each track, a feeling of someone thinking about everything they've ever been influenced by and trying to cram it all into a four-minute dash to the finish line-- smoky 80s cocktail jazz butting up against jungle drums and loping reggae basslines.

list.title: V
list.dek: Between September 2009 and September 2011, Barn Owl's Evan Caminiti and Jon Porras released four full-length albums, and several collaborative and solo LPs. After a release-free 2012, their return sees the pair augment their guitars with keyboard drones, digital rhythms, and kaleidoscopic synth hues.

list.title: Bankrupt!
list.dek: The French foursome's fifth album scans as a post-success commentary, dropping you into a fast-changing world of K-pop synth melodies, Californian glamor and Scandinavian leather where they appear distinctly uncomfortable. The only reliable constant is the band's winning, shiny, jacked-up formula.

list.title: Gordian
list.dek: As Cosmin TRG, bass music auteur Cosmin Nicolae made spare but spaced-out tech house on 2011's Simulat. With his new album, Gordian, Nicolae's gone from evolution to refinement, a paring down that feels like it's wringing every last idea out of the musical concepts he set into motion on his previous album.

list.title: Infestissumam
list.dek: Over the last few years, the mysterious, much-hyped Swedish band formerly known as Ghost have cultivated an alluring persona of subversion and symbolism. Infestissumam, their first album for a major label, follows their 2010 debut Opus Eponymous, a collection of old-school "Satanic" heavy metal with hooks as addictive as sin.

list.title: Anarchic
list.dek: The anarchist black metal movement forms a small but fascinating pocket in the extreme metal scene. The Vancouver duo Skagos' Anarchic is a sprawling, four-part composition that fills a double LP with a blend of graceful, shoegazey post-rock and blasts of raw-throated, left-leaning black metal.

list.title: Alphawaves
list.dek: On Alphawaves, Trans Am guitarist Phil Manley, along with drummer Jon Theodore (Mars Volta/Queens of the Stone Age), demonstrates an affinity for reappropriating the core tools of Neu! and other krautrock acts, and for carbon reproductions of various other styles. But this isn't tribute-band trash.

list.title: Excavation
list.dek: With Excavation, London-based electronic producer Bobby Krlic, aka the Haxan Cloak, offers a multifaceted roadmap of the afterlife. The record, his first for Tri Angle, is about the journey taken after death, and it's bold and domineering, the kind of music that towers over you and casts a giant, intimidating shadow.

list.title: Inspiration Information / Wings of Love
list.dek: This 2xCD reissue of brilliant, reclusive L.A. songwriter Shuggie Otis' 1974 masterwork Inspiration Information includes four extra tracks from that session along with Wings of Love, comprising 14 tracks that Otis recorded between 1975 and 2000. Combined, the collections feel like a parallel universe greatest-hits compilation, from a world where a label embraced Otis’s genius and eccentricity, instead of driving him away.

list.title: The Ol' Soul EP
list.dek: The Greenville, S.C., rapper and singer Alpoko Don joined Youtube about a year ago and started uploading his now very popular music videos. The Ol’ Soul EP, a collection of new songs and YouTube favorites, is an arresting rap record, unique in its minimalist sound and bathed in the fingerprints of the South's musical history.

list.title: Kill Uncle
list.dek: Kill Uncle, Morrissey's second solo LP, which has now been reissued with an alternate version of one of its songs, has a largely deserved reputation as his least distinctive. A minor album by a major artist, it still offers its own curious pleasures, particularly for the converted.

list.promoTitle: Music For Dancefloors: The KPM Music Library
list.dek: It's no surprise that KPM, a label famous for its deep collection of vintage "library music," has provided a rich source of samples over the years: The beats are mixed high, sound crisp, and are delivered with supreme confidence and precision. There's certainly a feeling of joy to much of the music here, but little or no sense of abandon.

list.title: Recurring Dream
list.dek: The Chicago drone-rockers' sophomore LP, Recurring Dream, is a mesmerizing record with a distinctly sinister edge. Even as you're drawn in by its narcotic murk, you can't quite shake the feeling that something terrible's happened that you just can't quite recall.

list.title: No Answer : Lower Floors

list.title: Overgrown
list.dek: James Blake's follow-up to his breakthrough self-titled album incorporates more gospel and R&B elements and a wider variety of textures. He successfully splits the difference between the sultry bedroom vibes of R&B’s resurgent Quiet Storm moment and the more mundane life of a British “bedroom” artist.

list.dek: Portland, Ore.'s, Toxic Holocaust, fronted by the babyfaced Joel Grind, play sleazy thrash with nuclear and Venom fixations. list.title: Ministry of Love
list.dek: While IO Echo are quick to flaunt kotos and kimonos as signifiers, their anticipated debut's neon-lit reveries and gothic glamour conjure a romantic ideal of their Los Angeles homebase. In nearly all aspects, the bombastic duo arrive fully formed, but it comes at a cost.

list.title: I Hear a New World
list.dek: In 1959, a couple years after Sputnik 1 was launched into orbit, the eccentric London audio engineer Joe Meek attempted “to create a picture in music of what could be up there in outer space.” With the release of this vinyl reissue more than 50 years later, I Hear a New World still sounds surreal, an alternate universe that infiltrated our own.

list.title: Totale Nite
list.dek: Merchandise aren't the first band to draw inspiration from 80s mope rock, but the Tampa, Fla., group's background in the hardcore and DIY community has given them an edge on your average gang of 20-something miserablists. On their latest LP*,* they tighten up their blend of weirdo tones and emo conviction.

list.dek: Alex Calder is a 23-year-old musician who previously played drums in Mac DeMarco's shaggy band Makeout Videotape; on his debut EP, he sounds very much like a kindered spirit and puts his own spin on DeMarco's clever slacker jams.

list.title: snakes/vultures/sulfate
list.dek: Best known as the drummer for Interpol, Sam Fogarino's solo album as a singer-songwriter has, at best, a white-knuckle grasp on competency. It features the Jesus Lizard's Duane Denison and former Secret Machine Brandon Curtis, but little of what distinguishes them as players.

list.title: The Terror
list.dek: The Flaming Lips' unrelenting new album retains Embryonic's weighty mood but deconstructs the instrumental bombast into skeletal, mechanical forms. Where its 2009 antecedent played on themes of environmental destruction, The Terror deals in personal turmoil-- loneliness, depression, and anxiety.

list.title: Cosy Moments
list.dek: Kinski's last album, Down Below It’s Chaos, featured a band that sounded like it was trying to escape its own skin. Their latest, Cosy Moments, doubles down on Down Below’s shift to hard rock, sounding at times like it was made in the band’s hometown of Seattle about 22 years ago.

list.title: Lil Ghetto Boy
list.dek: With a few exceptions, the only alumnus of heyday-era No Limit who’s been consistently releasing worthwhile music is New Orleans' Fiend. With Lil Ghetto Boy, his first tape of the year, he serves up a satisfying slab of weed-rap that supercedes even 2011’s excellent Tennis Shoes & Tuxedos.

list.title: Vanishing Point
list.dek: Vanishing Point is the first Mudhoney album in five years, and Steve Turner's erratic soloing, Dan Peters' hyperactive drum fills, and Mark Arm's righteous middle-aged rancor are so defiantly Mudhoney-sounding that they justify the price of admission.

list.title: 1017 Thug
list.dek: Atlanta rapper Young Thug marries the hook-bending sensibility of Future, the pill-addled yawp of Danny Brown, and the playful irreverance of Lil B with the guiding aura of Lil Wayne's experimental period. When he finds the right balance on 1017 Thug, it makes for some of the best, most fun-loving rap of the year.

list.title: Update
list.dek: Paul Rose has proven one of dance music's most inventive producers, someone who takes bass places it rarely frequents. This digital-only compilation cherrypicks highlights from his Scuba project's seven-year existence, abandoning chronology in favor of something approaching a narrative.

list.title: The Ascent
list.dek: The British rapper Wiley’s career seems to seesaw between rough-hewn respectability and goofy populism. The Ascent, his latest sweep into the second category, bows to the received wisdom of cramming as many guest artists, producers and stylistic tics as humanly possible into a 50-minute listen.

list.dek: The Besnard Lakes’ husband/wife team of Jace Lasek and Olga Gorea aren’t just songwriters who produce pop tunes; they're composers who create musical suites out of sweepingly melodic movements. Their fourth album is their most “composed” to date.

list.title: Haw
list.dek: The songs on M.C. Taylor's fourth album as Hiss Golden Messenger pose questions about spiritual doubt rather than offer the easy reassurances familiar to rousing, populist folk rock. He draws from traditional Piedmont music as well as AM Gold country, jazz, rock, and pop.

list.title: The Empire Never Ended
list.dek: Matt Shadetek co-founded Brooklyn’s Dutty Artz collective with DJ/rupture. The label's regarded as an educator in global beats and dance culture, but on The Empire Never Ended, Shadetek puts aside his wide-cast net to release a collection of hip-hop instrumentals, one featuring a Riff Raff cameo.

list.title: The Alchemist: The Best of Goldie 1992-2012

list.socialTitle: The Alchemist: The Best of Goldie 1992-2012
list.promoTitle: The Alchemist: The Best of Goldie 1992-2012
list.dek: There was a point in the late 90s where it looked like Clifford Price, aka Goldie, might be the first dance music artist to become a full-on mainstream megastar. The two discs of the new anthology The Alchemist: The Best Of Goldie 1992-2012 covering the span of Price’s career make a compelling argument that the world may finally be ready for him.

list.dek: The possibility that Lil Wayne's new album could be overshadowed by his recent health scare is confirmed by this rote, crass reassembly of what once made him great. Weezy called II "my bum-ass album" on his release from hospital: turns out he wasn't just being self-deprecating.

list.dek: The first release of the sole album by Senatobia's Sid Hemphill, the so-called "boar-hog musician of the hills," comes over 70 years after Alan Lomax first captured it on acetate. It's an extraordinary, strange, vehement collection that showcases Hemphill's singular yawp and absurd, infectious sense of humor.

list.title: Nostalchic
list.dek: Lapalux stands out as one of the more accessible producers on Flying Lotus’s Brainfeeder label. On his debut album Nostalchic, Stuart Howard moves from deconstructed pop to a more relaxed brand of R&B and soul, both genres that complement his consistent interest in texture.

list.title: Delta Machine
list.dek: Depeche Mode's thirteenth album sounds like it could be a set of outtakes from 1993's Songs of Faith and Devotion. On Delta Machine, they don't even bother pretending technology has opened up any possibilities for recorded sound in the past 20 years.
